name: SciOly DivB Rocks & Minerals — Week 1
desc: Division B — Week 1 image-only identification. Front = image only; Back = name + key properties. Tags: Week1, Mineral.

fields:
Aragonite — Carbonate (CaCO₃)
Hardness: 3.5–4
Streak: white
Luster: vitreous
Cleavage: distinct (orthorhombic; often needle/prismatic radiating clusters)
Key tests: vigorous fizz in cold dilute HCl; higher SG than calcite; different crystal habit
Notes/Uses: component of shells/corals; polymorph of calcite.

Calcite — Carbonate (CaCO₃)
Hardness: 3
Streak: white
Luster: vitreous
Cleavage: perfect rhombohedral (3 directions)
Key tests: strong fizz in cold dilute HCl; double refraction in clear rhombohedra
Notes/Uses: limestone/marble component; cement, acid neutralization.

Dolomite — Carbonate (CaMg(CO₃)₂)
Hardness: 3.5–4
Streak: white
Luster: vitreous to pearly
Cleavage: rhombohedral (3 directions)
Key tests: weak/no fizz in cold dilute HCl unless powdered or scratched; saddle-shaped crystals common
Notes/Uses: dolostone rock former; Mg source.

Malachite — Carbonate (Cu₂CO₃(OH)₂)
Hardness: 3.5–4
Streak: pale green
Luster: silky to vitreous
Cleavage: poor
Key tests: vivid banded green; effervesces slowly in HCl; may color acid green
Notes/Uses: copper ore; decorative stone.

Copper — Native element (Cu)
Hardness: ~3
Streak: copper-red
Luster: metallic
Cleavage: none; hackly fracture
Key tests: malleable/ductile; tarnishes green; high density
Notes/Uses: wiring, coins, alloys.

Diamond — Native element (C)
Hardness: 10 (Mohs)
Streak: none (white)
Luster: adamantine
Cleavage: perfect in 4 directions (octahedral)
Key tests: extreme hardness; high dispersion (sparkle)
Notes/Uses: gem; cutting/abrasive.

Gold — Native element (Au)
Hardness: 2.5–3
Streak: yellow
Luster: metallic
Cleavage: none; hackly fracture
Key tests: malleable; very high density; does not tarnish; distinct yellow color
Notes/Uses: jewelry, electronics, currency.

Graphite — Native element (C)
Hardness: 1–2
Streak: dark gray to black
Luster: metallic to earthy
Cleavage: basal; very soft/greasy feel
Key tests: writes on paper; very low SG compared to metallic minerals
Notes/Uses: pencils ("lead"), lubricants.

Silver — Native element (Ag)
Hardness: 2.5–3
Streak: silver-white
Luster: metallic (very bright)
Cleavage: none; hackly fracture
Key tests: malleable/ductile; tarnishes black (Ag₂S); high conductivity
Notes/Uses: electronics, jewelry, coins.

Sulfur — Native element (S)
Hardness: ~2
Streak: white
Luster: resinous
Cleavage: poor; brittle
Key tests: bright yellow color; low density; burns with blue flame and pungent odor (⚠️ do not burn samples at home)
Notes/Uses: fertilizer, chemicals.
